entry.title: AI Infrastructure & ML Systems Overview
entry.content:
Evolution of AI Infrastructure

Stage 1: 2016-2017 - MXNet Era

  • AWS MXNet (later donated to Apache)
  • DeepEngine
  • Amazon SageMaker

Stage 2: Meta PyTorch Revolution

  • E.g. PyTorch Accelerator enablement: Model deployment and application enablement
  • State-of-the-art (SOTA) implementations
  • CUDA kernel optimization
  • Compiler advancements

Stage 3: Hardware Optimization

  • Focus on GPU efficiency
  • Cost reduction in training

AI Infrastructure in Engineering

Both involves Research & Development.

Framework

  • ML System
  • Hardware cost optimization

Platform

  • Inference platform
  • Training platform
  • Cluster management

AI Infrastructure Engineer’s Scope

Core Objectives

  • Making AGI development more cost-effective and faster
  • Hardware-software co-design
  • System architecture (OSDI, NSDI)
  • Model training and inference expertise
  • Transformer architecture
  • Generative AI systems

Current Applications

  • Enterprise solutions (RAG, agents)
  • The “One-person Billion-dollar Company” concept

Career Development Paths

For New Graduates

  1. Education

    • AI and ML system courses
    • Online ML systems courses

  2. Project Experience

    • GenAI projects
      • Infrastructure track: Performance metrics (latency improvement, throughput supported)
      • Research track: Algorithm improvements, hardware co-design

  3. Open Source Contributions

    • Popular projects (PyTorch, vLLM, SGLang)
    • Focus on throughput and latency optimization

For 3-5 Years Experience

  • Strategic career planning
  • Transition opportunities:
    • Backend/database ->
    • AI platform, infrastructure and serving (AI storage solutions, etc.) ->
    • Career move
  • Current advantage: Emerging field with equal opportunity
  • Continuous learning and adaptation
  • Emphasis on design and implementation

For AI Infrastructure Managers

  • Domain expertise requirements
  • Focus areas:
    • 20-30% design review
    • People management
    • Less hands-on coding

Learning Resources

Educational Content

  • AI System School (Uncle Moon)
  • Andrej Karpathy’s YouTube series:
    • Basic MLP implementation
    • Transformer model development
    • Model training techniques

Academic Programs

  • Berkeley/CMU ML Systems courses
  • Stanford ML Systems webinars (weekly)

Community Resources

  • CUDA/GPU programming communities
  • Technical meetups
  • Open source project participation

Career Transition Preparation

Key Areas

  1. Technical Skills

    • LeetCode practice
    • System design study
    • Technical blog reading

  2. Timing Strategy

    • Monitor headcount availability
      • Headcounts are usually out after yearly planning
    • Early application preparation
      • Don’t wait, start interviews process asap
    • Proactive networking

Open Source Projects in AI Infrastructure

Training and Serving

  1. vLLM
  2. SGLang

AI Native Cloud Platforms

  • Enhanced observability
  • Improved debugging capabilities

Agent Systems

  • Inter-agent coordination
  • Plug-and-play memory systems
  • Context fetching optimization

Startup Landscape

Pre-LLM Era

  • Databricks (Spark-based)
  • Anyscale (Ray-based)
  • Focus on compute, storage, networking

Current Landscape

  • Model serving infrastructure
  • Abstraction layers for different model providers
  • Enable users to quick build a compound AI system
  • Notable companies:
    • Fireworks AI
    • Lepton
    • Together AI

entry.title: System design 101 (WIP)
entry.content:
System design topics

Performance vs Scalability

  • A performance problem: your system is slow for a single user.
  • A scalability problem: your system is fast for a single user, but slow under heavy load.

Latency vs Throughput

  • Latency: time to perform some action or to produce some result.
  • Throughtput: number of such actions or results per unit of time.
  • Aim for macimmal throughtput with acceptable latency.

Availability vs Consistency

CAP theorem

In a distributed computer system, you can only support 2 of the following guarantees:

  • Contsistency: every read receives the most recent write or an error.
  • Availability: every request receives a response, without guarantee that it contains the most recent version of the information.
  • Partition Tolerance: the system continues to operate despite arbitrary partitioning due to network failures.

Networks are not reliable, so partition tolerance needs to be supported. We need to make a software tradeoff between consistency and availability.

CP (consistency & partition tolerance)

  • Waiting for a resopnse from the partitioned node might result in a timeout error.
  • CP is a good choice if your business requires atomic reads and writes.

AP (availability & partition tolerance)

  • Responses return the most readily available version of the data available on any node, which might not be the latest. Writes might take some time to propagate when the partition is resolved.
  • AP is a good choice if your business needs to allow for eventual consistency or when the system needs to continue working despite external errors.

Consistency patterns

Weak consistency

After a write, reads may or may not see it. A best effort approach is taken.

E.g. memcached, VoIP, video chat, realtime multiplayer games. (If you are on a phone call and lose reception for a few second, when you regain connection you do not hear what was spoken during connection loss.)

Eventual consistency

After a write, reads will eventually see it (typically within milliseconds). Data is replicated asynchronously.

E.g. DNS, email, highly available systems.

Strong consistency

After a write, reads will see it. Data is replicated synchronously.

E.g. file systems, RDBMSes, systems that need transactions.

Availability patterns

Fail-over

Active-passive

  • Heartbeats are sent between the active and the passive server on standby. If the heartbeat is interrupted, the passive server takes over the active’s IP address and resumes service.
  • The length of downtime is determined by whether the passive server is already running in ‘hot’ standby or whether it needs to start up from ‘cold’ standby; only the active server handles traffic.
  • Can also be referred to as master-slave fail-over.

Active-active

  • Both servers are managing traffic, spreading the load between them.
  • If the servers are public-facing, the DNS would need to know about the public IPs of both servers; if the servers are internal-facing, application logic would need to know about both servers.
  • Can also be referred to as master-master fail-over.

Disadvantages of fail-over

  • Adds more hardware and additional complexity.
  • There’s a potential for loss of data if the active system fails before any newly written data can be replicated to the passive.

Replication

Futher discussed in the Database section.

  • Master-slave replication
  • Master-master replication

Availability in numbers

Availability is often quantified by uptime (or downtime) as a percentage of time the service is available.

Availability is measured in number of 9s (a service with 99.99% availability is described as having four 9s).

  • 99.9% availability -> three 9s (8h 45min 57s downtime per year)
  • 99.99% availability -> four 9s (52min 35.7s downtime per year)

Availability in parallel vs in sequence

  • If a service consists of multiple components prone to failure, the service’s overall availability depends on whether the components are in sequence or in parallel.
    • In sequence
      • Availability (components) < 100% -> Availability (total) ↓
      • Availability (total) = Availability (foo) * Availability (bar)
    • In parallel
      • Availability (components) < 100% -> Availability (total) ↑
      • Availability (total) = 1 - (1 - Availability (foo)) * (1 - Availability(bar))

entry.title: My journey at IKEA Digital Hub
entry.content:
Last year, I worked as a full-time Software Engineer Intern at IKEA for 10 months. My job was mainly delivering frontends for the IKEA WeChat SMP. I also contributed to the static webpage library for the APP/SMP team.

Project overview

The project I mainly worked on during my internship is called IKEA WeChat SMP.

I created reusable components like address selector, broadcast popups, configurable floating buttons, advertisement card, etc. and I also designed and implemented product inventory module, optimized logic for delivery, live stream, checkout and coupons.

If you are a WeChat user, you can search for the IKEA WeChat SMP program in WeChat.

What we built is basically the online shopping center of IKEA integrated in WeChat, which is the most widely used (1.25 billion monthly active users) social app in China.

I was lucky enough to participate in the initial building work and witness the official nationwide launch of this project. This project achieved 6x,xxx average daily active users with 6xx.xK RMB average sales per day after the official launch.

A day in my life at IKEA

My work time was usually from 9:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday to Friday.

Morning routine: Stand-up meeting

Every morning when I arrived at our office building, our team would have a daily stand-up meeting to talk about our progress and check the obstacles in our work. It was usually about 10 minutes, and it marked the start of my day at work.

This was also my best chance to know about what other people in my team were working on. Gradually, I gained a more comprehensive understanding of the projects’ status in my team as well.

Sprint start: getting my tasks on JIRA

Since I worked in a Scrum team, we had sprints. A sprint is like an iteration period. A normal sprint was 2 weeks usually. When the sprint started, we would have an Iteration (or Sprint) Planning Meeting (IPM). In this meeting, we would discuss how much of the backlog could be committed to and delivered in this sprint. The tasks would be evaluated in story points.

After the sprint started, I would have several tasks on JIRA which showed the work I needed to get done in this sprint. I was also responsible to update my task status every day.

Sprint ongoing: develop, discuss, and deliver

During the sprint, I would discuss some ambiguous points with the Product Owner and code to meet the expectations. This process also included a lot of conversations with the UI/UX designer, the Quality Assurance Engineer, the Backend Development Engineer, and even people from other teams or departments.

At first I was super shy and it was a big challenge for me to gather the courage to start conversations with so many people. It was because of how nice the people here were that made me comfortable to express my opinion and become more and more confident.

When I thought my code was ready, I would inform a QA Engineer to put my code into testing. When the testings were passed, and the PO thought it fulfilled the acceptance criteria, my code would go online to our shopping program for people to use.

Snacks were amazing!!

Here we had different kinds of snacks and fruit every day. I loved the cheesecakes - I know it’s not that healthy - which were so beautiful and delicious. The kiwis here were always sweeter than the ones I brought from the market. And when there was an activity or party, we had more. There were yogurt, bread, chocolate cake, fried chicken, meatballs, sausages, cookies, sushis, more than ten kinds of drinks…

Summary

2020 was definitely a special year for many people. For me as well.

Instead of pursuing my graduate study right after finishing my undergrad study as I originally planned, I was “forced” by COVID-19 to take a gap year and did my first formal internship in life. I was lucky enough to spend that year with people at IKEA.

I wanted to thank everyone in my team, who was the kindest person and most willing to answer my questions at any time. I also wanted to especially thank my line manager Leo and my mentor, Ciki, who perfected my internship.

When I first arrived at IKEA, I almost knew nothing about real-industry software development. Ciki was always happy to give me useful instructions and show me the right direction to work in.

It was a great time working here, and the people here were so welcoming and so supportive to me.

See you, IKEA!

Quick notes of the Linkedin Learning Course “Scrum: The Basics” by Kelley O’Connell, with my own experience in the workspace.

Problems to Solve

What does the Team’s BACKLOG contain?

A: a prioritized list of work that must be done

Select something Scrum Teams do at the end of every sprint.

A: Demonstrate the completed work.

In the Agile Manifesto, Scrum values _.

A: responding to change

The Heart of the Framework

Agile Project:

  • Product Owner
  • Scrum Master

What are the 3 normal project constraints?

time, cost, scope

Product Owner and Scrum Master
